caption_original: In the spirit of reconciliation and building on partnerships established through the Nunangat Declaration, the Government of Canada signed a partnership agreement with Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada to address issues of common concern that directly affect the well-being and safety of Inuit women and children across Canada. Learn more: ow.ly/eHxW100HRwY

caption_original: Congratulations to partners involved in the development of the Nunavut Wellness Agreement. Through this agreement, the Government of Canada will provide funding to the Government of Nunavut for community-based programs covering four broad areas: healthy children, families and communities; healthy living; mental wellness; and home and community care. Learn more about the Nunavut Wellness Agreement:  http://ow.ly/V5lA30cQH0B

Experience the Arctic through music! Musical duo Twin Flames will perform on June 10, 2017 at the  Canadian Museum of Nature - Musée canadien de la nature in Ottawa, Ontario. Together, Chelsey June (Algonquin/Cree/Metis) and Jaaji (Inuk/Mohawk) sing songs in English, French and Inuktitut. 
For further details on this event: http://ow.ly/r2LD30cqE2T

caption_original: DYK The word "Alianait" means “joy” or “it’s wonderful!” in some Inuit languages? From June 30 – July 3, Iqaluit (Nunavut) is hosting the Alianait Arts Festival festival, bringing together performers from all across the circumpolar region and other parts of Canada, including acrobats, musicians, dance troops, storytellers and more. Check out all there is to see and do: http://ow.ly/u8z830cQDDl

caption_original: Explore the Northwest Territories at Nahanni National Park Reserve! Called Nah?a Dehé by the Dehcho people, this UNESCO World Heritage Site offers a unique display of geological formations. Climbers, hikers, paddlers and visitors of all kinds are welcomed to the land by the Dehcho First Nations. http://ow.ly/DyCj30cB0g3

caption_original:
Biology students from École St. Patrick High School in Yellowknife, NWT, learned about environmental monitoring from biologists working on the Giant Mine Remediation Project. Students received hands-on experience with the Giant Mine Remediation Project team on how environmental monitoring helps ensure the safety, health and protection of Northerners and the environment. 

While students took samples of invertebrates (small bugs), water, sediment, and small fish for live release from the Yellowknife River, project team members explained how the different types of sampling help evaluate the health of an ecosystem.  The Project team was excited to show students a real-life application of the science they are learning in the classroom.
caption_cleaned: Biology students from École St. Patrick High School in Yellowknife, NWT, learned about environmental monitoring from biologists working on the Giant Mine Remediation Project. Students received hands-on eerience with the Giant Mine Remediation Project team on how environmental monitoring helps ensure the safety, health and protection of Northerners and the environment. While students took samples of invertebrates (small bugs), water, sediment, and small fish for live release from the Yellowknife River, project team members elained how the different types of sampling help evaluate the health of an ecosystem. The Project team was excited to show students a real-life application of the science they are learning in the classroom.
